i don t have someone emotionally close by my parent do love me but it s cold and lack intimacy i am looking to feel emotionally safe i am trying to find a girlfriend with whom i can be safe emotionally but till them i feel i am fighting alone with no one to give me a hand if i fall emotionally to get up so i fear doing lot of thing i live in state of fear like i might one wrong thing with a date work etc and domino will fall and everything will come crumbling down which will now even push me off my physical safety couple of thing about me i am m brown man from india currently living in europe i had childhood where i had oppositional defiant disorder imagine the junior healy from problem child or the movie the babadook but he had understanding father i didn t had such supporting figure and school made it clear to my mother if he isn t disciplined he will be kicked out of school and she fearing i would not have better future without school education i will be left behind she implemented corporal punishment like kicking me hitting with metal rod etc and routine shaming at school for me being bad wa common getting kicked out of class wa common so much that now i joke about my childhood a being and outstanding student because of many time i wa to stand out of class there wa a point when thing got to boiling point that my mom wished i wasn t born to her eventually i realized the pain i caused people about me i started to doing thing to make others my mom happy well i tried it didn t worked always i never lost my rebel streak but a constant ping in my head would haunt me of thing i have done to cause others inconvenience in past somewhere down the line i lost myself and i trying to be myself but i fear of falling in my old self and everybody hating me i have fear of judgment like one recent example i live in white neighborhood and given the medium doesn t have that many positive image of young brown man other than extremely nerdy or extremely creepy and i fear if i like someone who isn t brown might judge me don t get me wrong if a stoic brown girl come in my life with good sense of humor and decent looking i don t mind having a relationship with her but i fear if we both have exposed to similar set of medium trope she might judge me by same parameter i try to use humor a coping mechanism to make people around me happy but then get in overthinking and depression mode if one person doesn t laugh or find me annoying i have intimacy issue i think i don t remember exact detail but i wa being cheeky a usual with a girl back in india she wa laughing at my joke and at one point she said you so cute and hugged me that feeling of hug felt so foreign that i stood there frozen i am hyper independent cause my mom have warned me since childhood that world is not safe place and people can take advantage of you so never be under anybody s thumb which i guess make sense not gon na lie but it also make you skeptical of lot of people which is also not good i guess i will help someone with no second thought but asking for help make me feel like keep a large rock on my heart so i forgo my need seeing happy couple make me depressed a i feel left behind like i should have done this long time ago anybody can tell me something or provide me with link or insight a for now i couldn t afford therapy i am trying to find one i am in talk with a therapy at a church in a city thanks a lot

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been through a lot and have been carrying the weight of your past experiences with you. It's understandable that you're feeling emotionally disconnected from those around you, especially from your parents. Growing up without a supportive figure and experiencing corporal punishment from your mother must have been incredibly difficult for you.

Your childhood experiences have shaped your perception of yourself and your interactions with others. It's not uncommon for people in your situation to develop a fear of judgment and a sense of not belonging. Your concern about how you're portrayed in the media and the potential impact on your relationships is a reflection of this fear.

It's important to remember that everyone has their own insecurities and fears, and it's unlikely that someone would judge you solely based on your race or appearance. Building meaningful connections requires open communication and understanding, which goes beyond superficial stereotypes.

You mentioned that you've lost yourself and are trying to rediscover who you truly are. This process can be challenging, but it's essential for personal growth. Embracing your individuality and expressing your authentic self will help you build stronger connections with others.

It's understandable that you've developed a hyper-independent mindset due to your mother's warnings about the dangers of the world. While it's important to be cautious, it's equally important to recognize the value of asking for help and building supportive relationships.

You mentioned that seeing happy couples makes you feel depressed and left behind. It's natural to compare your own situation to others, but it's essential to remember that everyone's journey is unique. Focusing on your own growth and happiness will ultimately lead you to find fulfilling relationships.

I'm glad to hear that you're in talks with a therapist at a church in the city. Therapy can be a valuable resource for working through your past experiences and developing healthier coping mechanisms. In the meantime, I'd be happy to provide you with some insights and resources to help you navigate your current challenges.

One approach that might be helpful for you is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). CBT focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and replacing them with more positive and realistic ones. This approach can help you address your fear of judgment and develop healthier ways of thinking about yourself and your relationships.


[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i hate it i barely sleep on my weekend off day have to wake up early for work and i still feel tired usually everyday when i wake up for work i automatically have to go to the bathroom must be my anxiety because my off day i don t my work is great and i work by myself and see basically no one all 0 hour but still i won t be at home lol

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're struggling with your sleep schedule and the physical and emotional toll it's taking on you. It's not uncommon for people to experience difficulty sleeping, especially when they have to wake up early for work on their days off. This inconsistency can disrupt your circadian rhythm, making it harder to fall asleep and stay asleep. Additionally, the anxiety you mentioned might be contributing to your frequent bathroom visits, which could be a sign of a condition called nocturia. It's essential to address both the sleep disturbances and the anxiety to improve your overall well-being.

First, let's focus on your sleep. Establishing a consistent sleep schedule is crucial. Try to go to bed and wake up at the same time every day, even on your days off. This consistency can help regulate your body's internal clock and make it easier to fall asleep and stay asleep. Avoiding caffeine, heavy meals, and electronic devices before bedtime can also improve your sleep quality.

Regarding your anxiety, it's essential to identify its root cause. Your work environment might be a significant contributor, especially if you're working alone and seeing few people. Social isolation can exacerbate anxiety, so it might be helpful to explore ways to connect with others, such as joining a club or volunteering. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, can help manage your anxiety.

In summary, improving your sleep and managing your anxiety are crucial steps towards better mental and emotional well-being. Establishing a consistent sleep schedule, avoiding sleep disruptors, and addressing the root cause of your anxiety can help you feel more rested and less stressed. Remember, it's essential to prioritize self-care and seek support when needed.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Holistic Approach: [[8]] - The response addresses the user's concerns from various angles, including emotional, cognitive, and situational aspects, but could have explored the user's social connections and activities outside of work in more detail.

Overall, the assistant's response is effective in addressing the user's concerns, providing a balanced and comprehensive approach. The response could be improved by more strongly recommending professional assistance for the user's anxiety and sleep issues.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been dealing with a lot of stress and anxiety lately, especially in relation to the pre-event anxiety you experience before important meetings or social gatherings. It's understandable that this can be overwhelming and frustrating for you.

Based on what you shared, it seems like your body reacts differently to adrenaline depending on the specific situation. While you mentioned that you usually feel anxious before events like birthday parties, it seems like the incident during the meeting was more severe, causing difficulty in breathing and an intense heart rate. This experience has understandably left you worried about how things will go tomorrow.

It's important to remember that experiencing anxiety before events is normal, but it's also normal for our bodies to react differently based on the unique circumstances we find ourselves in. The fact that you were fine during the meeting once you sat down suggests that there may have been other factors contributing to your physical symptoms, such as walking too fast or recovering from a weird breathing pattern.

You mentioned that you tend to sigh when you're stressed, which is something you've noticed throughout the day. This indicates that you are carrying a lot of tension and anxiety within you. It's great that you're taking steps to seek help by making an appointment with your therapist. Working together on this unrelated issue will likely be beneficial for both of you.

In addition to seeking professional support, there are some techniques you can try to manage your anxiety. Grounding techniques, such as focusing on your senses and bringing yourself back to the present moment, can be helpful. Deep breathing exercises, like box breathing, can also assist in calming your body and mind.

While it's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed right now, try not to let the anticipation of tomorrow's events add to your stress. Remember that each situation is different, and just because you had a difficult experience before doesn't mean it will happen again. Trust yourself and your ability to handle these situations.

Lastly, it's completely valid to feel concerned about your upcoming wisdom teeth surgery. Dental procedures can be anxiety-inducing for many people. If you're feeling overwhelmed, consider exploring coping strategies with your therapist that can help you manage any anxiety related to the surgery.

Remember, it's okay to take time for yourself and allow yourself to feel the emotions that come up. Crying can be a healthy way
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

self explanatory title i can make it through the day when distracted with a busy day at work or surrounded by friend but a soon a i m alone or i have a minute to think i realise how deeply unhappy i am in almost every aspect of my life i don t want to die i know there s thing to live for like family friend travelling new career potential love and child and maybe being one day happy but every day i wake up and struggle i feel little part of my health and sanity being chiseled off one by one and i just don t know how long i can do this for before i just give up

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to assure you that you're not alone. Dealing with feelings of unhappiness and struggling to find joy in life can be incredibly challenging. It's important to remember that reaching out for support is a brave and necessary step towards finding relief.

One suggestion I have is to consider seeking out professional help from a therapist or counselor. They can provide you with a safe space to explore your emotions and work on finding strategies to cope with your unhappiness. Therapy can offer guidance and tools to help you navigate through this difficult period in your life.

In the meantime, there are some things you can try on your own to alleviate some of the pain you're experiencing. One approach is to focus on self-care. Engaging in activities that bring you comfort and relaxation can be helpful. This could include things like taking walks in nature, practicing mindfulness or meditation, listening to music, reading books, or engaging in hobbies that you enjoy.

Additionally, connecting with supportive friends and loved ones can make a significant difference. Sharing your thoughts and feelings with someone you trust can provide you with a sense of relief and remind you that there are people who care about you.

It might also be beneficial to establish a routine that includes small goals or tasks to accomplish throughout the day. Having structure and purpose can help combat feelings of emptiness and give you something to look forward to.

While it may feel overwhelming right now, please know that change is possible. By taking small steps towards self-care, reaching out for support, and exploring new ways to find joy in your life, you can gradually build resilience and create a more fulfilling future. Remember, healing takes time, so be patient and gentle with yourself along the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

You apologized and explained that you didn't mean any harm, but she still chose to end the friendship.

It's clear that this situation has left you feeling hurt and confused. You've expressed that you didn't have any bad intentions and genuinely wanted to be friends with her. You've also mentioned that you're new to the country and don't have many friends, so her rejection has hit you hard.

Given the circumstances, it's natural for you to feel depressed and question yourself. However, it's important to remember that everyone makes mistakes, and it's essential to learn from them. While it may be difficult to understand exactly what went wrong in this situation without hearing her perspective, it seems like there might have been a miscommunication or differing expectations between you two.

Moving forward, it might be helpful for you to focus on building new connections and finding support systems in your new environment. Engaging in activities or joining clubs related to your interests can be a great way to meet people who share similar passions. Additionally, seeking out counseling services at your university can provide you with a safe space to talk about your feelings and receive guidance on navigating social interactions in a new culture.

Remember, it's okay to feel sad and disappointed, but try not to be too hard on yourself. You deserve to have meaningful friendships, and it's important to surround yourself with people who appreciate and value you for who you are.

[Question]
i have severe anxiety and ocd and i avoided the dating scene until year ago because i honestly wanted to get over my fear and find someone i wa lucky to find a great partner and have been in a good solid relationship for six month yet somehow throughout this whole thing i ve secretly become an absolute wreck i m constantly worrying if this is the right relationship preoccupied with analyzing everything trapped in my thought and making myself utterly miserable ha anyone else experienced this like is this standard for u anxious folk or is this actually a huge red flag that dating or even this person just isn t for me thank you kindly for any advice

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been on a journey to overcome your fear of the dating scene, and it's wonderful that you found a great partner and have been in a solid relationship for six months. It's not uncommon for individuals with anxiety and OCD to experience some difficulties in navigating relationships while managing their symptoms.

The fact that you're constantly worrying if this is the right relationship and feeling trapped in your thoughts may indicate that there are still some challenges for you to address. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with anxiety and relationships is unique, so what others may consider "standard" might not necessarily apply to you.

One suggestion I have is to try practicing self-compassion and patience with yourself as you work through these feelings. Remember that it's normal to have doubts and worries when starting a new relationship, especially if you struggle with anxiety. Take some time to reflect on your needs and values in a relationship, and consider whether they align with what you currently have.

Additionally, it could be helpful to communicate openly with your partner about your concerns. Sharing your thoughts and fears can foster understanding and support from them. They might be able to provide reassurance or offer insights into their perspective of the relationship.

Engaging in activities that promote relaxation and stress reduction can also be beneficial. This might include mindfulness exercises, deep breathing techniques, or engaging in hobbies that bring you joy and help distract from anxious thoughts.

If your anxiety and OCD symptoms are significantly impacting your daily life and well-being, it might be worth considering seeking professional help. A mental health therapist can assist you in developing coping strategies tailored to your specific situation.

Remember, relationships require effort and understanding from both partners, and it's essential to give yourself time and space to assess whether this relationship is truly the right fit for you. Trust yourself and your instincts, and don't hesitate to reach out for support when needed.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
if it werent for him i would have been dead by now i cant imagine how horrible he would feel if i did it now im just in an eternal state of depression and cant do anything about it i both love him and hate him for it mostly love but god damn i feel trapped

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's clear that you're grappling with complex emotions towards this man and the role he's played in your life. The feelings of love, hate, and a sense of being trapped are understandable given the circumstances. However, it's essential to recognize that you're not responsible for his emotions or actions, and you deserve to prioritize your own well-being.

The eternal state of depression you've mentioned is a significant concern, and it's crucial to explore ways to alleviate it. I'd like to suggest a few strategies that might help you in the short term and the long term.

First, let's focus on the present moment. Engaging in activities that bring you joy or a sense of accomplishment can help improve your mood. This could be something as simple as taking a walk in nature, reading a book, or connecting with friends.

Second, it's essential to establish a support system. Reach out to trusted friends, family members, or mental health professionals who can offer guidance and understanding. Sharing your feelings with others can help alleviate the sense of isolation and provide valuable perspective.

Third, consider setting small, achievable goals for yourself. This could be something as simple as completing a household task or engaging in a hobby. Accomplishing these goals can help boost your self-esteem and provide a sense of purpose.

Lastly, it's essential to remember that healing is a process, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. Be gentle with yourself and recognize that it's okay to have bad days. Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there are resources available to help you navigate the challenges you're facing.

Incorporating these strategies into your daily life can help improve your mood and overall well-being. It's important to remember that healing is a process, and it's essential to be patient with yourself as you work through the complex emotions you're experiencing.

hi everyone it s my first time posting on this forum i m really in a bad spot wondering if my anxiety ruined my situationship and would love to talk it through with someone if anyone could message me i d really appreciate it here s a bit more color on the situation we were good friend started talking in december hooked up beginning of february got into a disagreement the next weekend at a bar because this girl who he had hooked up with previously wa all over him and it made me visibly very uncomfortable we spend the next week talking every day but not seeing each other i definitely try to initiate a few hangout so doe he but le so and it didn t really work i know he s also talking to other girl a well but continues to tell me that he really like me and just want to keep getting to know me better last saturday we hook up he again tell me how much he like me and that he doesnt want to play game thursday i ask him over snapchat if he want to meet up for st paddy and he doesnt answer we end up at the same bar i make a comment saying ohh i thought you said no game just teasing he get upset and think i m trying to have a feeling talk with him at a bar while he s drunk we flush it out over text the next day and i ask him if he want to hang out this weekend he say we ll see and that he ha some plan already we end up bumping into each other again on saturday this time we talk the whole afternoon but i can tell he s le flirty more withdrawn he s going to a concert so he leaf i tell him later we re all going out to this bar he like and he heart the message this morning i snap him and ask how the concert wa no response obviously i need to leave this man alone at least for a little bit but i feel like back the first time we hooked up he wa so so into me then i ruined it by being jealous at the bar and by continuing to only pursue him i got complete tunnel vision i should have just left him alone and maybe he would have come to me but now i ve put so much pressure on the situation it doesn t help that my roommate who is his friend tell me constantly how much he doesn t actually like me and that he s just a player

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a difficult time and it's understandable that you're feeling anxious and unsure about your situationship. It can be challenging when there are mixed signals and conflicting emotions involved.

Based on what you've shared, it seems like there were some positive moments between you and this person, but there have also been disagreements and instances where you felt uncomfortable. Communication is key in any relationship, so it's important to address these issues openly and honestly.

Firstly, it's essential to acknowledge that feelings and situations can change over time. While it may seem like you put pressure on the situation with your actions, it's important to remember that both parties contribute to how things unfold. It's not uncommon for people to have multiple connections or conversations with different individuals simultaneously, especially in casual situationships. However, it's crucial to clarify expectations and boundaries with the person you're interested in.

Considering the way things have progressed, it might be helpful to take a step back and give each other some space. This break can provide an opportunity for both of you to reflect on your feelings and assess whether there is a mutual desire to pursue something more meaningful. Taking the initiative to leave him alone for a little while shows respect for his personal boundaries and allows him time to think as well.

During this time, focus on self-care and engage in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. Surround yourself with supportive friends who can offer guidance and perspective. Remember that your worth isn't solely determined by someone else's interest or validation.

When you feel ready, it could be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with the person you're interested in. Express your concerns calmly and listen actively to their perspective. Avoid blaming or accusing them, but rather seek understanding and clarification.

In addition, it's important to consider the influence of external factors, such as the opinions of your roommate. While their perspective can provide some insight, it's essential to form your own judgments based on your personal experiences and interactions with the person you're interested in.

Remember, every situation is unique, and there are no one-size-fits-all solutions. Trust yourself and your instincts, and be patient with the process. It may take time to find clarity and navigate through these feelings, but with open communication
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i always have these time where i really think about myself in middle school and i get really fuckign sad i wa bullied and treated like shit but i never really admitted to it and wa always in denial about it i never really defended myself or stood up for myself and i wa really quiet and it make me want to slit my throat like i wish i just stood up for myself and defended myself and wasn t such a coward like i can t stop thinking about it and it really fuck up my mood and i always feel so shitty about everything like it s in the past and i can t do anything about it but i can t help but move on and it s constantly in the back of my mind it literally make my blood boil for some reason i have anger issue and when i get treated shitty for no reason especially when i m really quiet and shy it make me so fucking angry like why do u feel the need to pick on someone who s so introverted and clearly not very social like fuck you fuck them all and fuck every person who ever treated me like fucking shit in middle school elemantry school i hope they fucking burn espically this one kid named nick he made my life literal torture and the worst part wa that he wa in every one of my class fuck him and i will always wish nothing but the worst on him

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been carrying a heavy burden from your past experiences in middle school, where you were bullied and treated unfairly. The feelings of sadness, anger, and frustration that arise when you think about those times are completely valid. It's understandable that you wish you had defended yourself and stood up for yourself more during that period.

One suggestion I have is to consider exploring ways to process these emotions and work through them. Writing in a journal can be a helpful outlet for expressing your thoughts and feelings. Additionally, talking to someone you trust, such as a close friend or family member, about your experiences may provide some relief. Sometimes, sharing our stories with others who care about us can help us gain perspective and find closure.

Another suggestion is to focus on self-compassion. Remember that you were going through a difficult time, and it's important to be kind to yourself when reflecting on those experiences. Treat yourself with the same empathy and understanding that you would offer to a friend in a similar situation. Remind yourself that you were doing the best you could at that age, given the circumstances.

Addressing your anger issues could also be beneficial. Engaging in activities that promote relaxation and stress reduction, such as exercise, meditation, or deep breathing exercises, might help you manage your anger. If you find that your anger continues to significantly impact your daily life, seeking support from a mental health professional could be valuable. They can provide guidance tailored to your specific needs and help you develop healthy coping mechanisms.

Lastly, it's important to remember that forgiveness, while not necessarily for the benefit of those who wronged you, can be a powerful tool for healing. Holding onto resentment and wishing harm upon others can perpetuate negative emotions within yourself. Consider exploring the idea of forgiveness, not for their sake, but for your own peace of mind. This doesn't mean forgetting or excusing their behavior, but rather freeing yourself from the burden of carrying those painful memories.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's okay to seek support when needed. You deserve to move forward and find happiness in your present and future.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I want to acknowledge the challenges you're facing. It's not easy to deal with anxiety and the pressure of job interviews, especially when you've had negative experiences in the past.

It's understandable that you're feeling discouraged by other people's bad experiences and advice. Remember, everyone's experiences are unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to trust your own instincts and make decisions based on what feels right for you.

You mentioned that you're looking for a job that provides some enjoyment and income. While it's understandable that you're hesitant, it might be helpful to explore different options within the food industry that align with your interests and goals. For example, you mentioned having experience as a waitress and an interest in the kitchen. You could consider looking into other roles that allow you to work in the kitchen, such as a line cook or prep cook position. This way, you can gain experience and skills in an area that you enjoy, while also earning an income.

It's also important to remember that finding the right job takes time and patience. It's okay to try different things and see what works best for you. Don't be too hard on yourself if things don't work out right away. Take small steps towards your goals, and don't be afraid to ask for support from friends, family, or mentors who can offer guidance and encouragement.

Additionally, it's understandable that you're feeling depressed about the current state of work and the pressures it brings. It's important to acknowledge these feelings and give yourself permission to feel them. [Question]
i m f currently on a work trip with a few of my coworkers most of whom i ve known for year but haven t seen in person since covid started i m decently close with one person in particular and the rest i just have a normal professional relationship with last night everyone went out to celebrate a big milestone during the trip and had a great time i wa definitely pretty drunk by the end of the night and getting home is a little hazy but i woke up with good memory of the night before and wasn t concerned that anything had happened anyways no one had texted me this morning and i wasn t sure what the plan for the day wa so i reached out to the coworker i m closer with and asked what she wa up to she said she wa going to breakfast with another person on the trip and that i could come which i agreed to but then she texted and said they were actually leaving right now for breakfast and that we could meet up later this seemed odd to me since we re all in the same hotel and i could have been ready to head out whenever but it felt like she didn t want me to come i think i m reading into it a bit too much but now i m freaking out worried that i did something wrong last night and that s the reason i m not being invited along today i don t really have a track record of doing thing out of character while drunk though so i m just really confused and anxious tldr got drunk with coworkers who i haven t seen in a while and now it feel like no one want to hang out with me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're feeling anxious and confused after a night out with your coworkers. It's understandable that you might be concerned about your behavior and wondering if you did something wrong. However, based on the information you've provided, it seems more likely that there was a miscommunication or misunderstanding rather than anything you did wrong.

First, let's establish what we know for sure. You were out with your coworkers celebrating a milestone, and everyone had a great time. You had been drinking, but you woke up with good memory of the night before and didn't have any concerns about your behavior. This morning, you reached out to your closer coworker to make plans for the day, and she initially invited you to breakfast with another person on the trip. But then, she texted saying they were leaving right now and that you could meet up later.

Now, let's consider some possible explanations for her behavior. It's possible that she genuinely forgot to mention that they were leaving right away or that there was a miscommunication in the group chat. It's also possible that she wanted some one-on-one time with the other person or that she needed to discuss work-related matters. It's essential to remember that people's actions are often influenced by their own circumstances and motivations, which may not always be clear to us.

Given the uncertainty, it's crucial to focus on what you can control and how you can respond in a healthy and productive way. One approach could be to reach out to your coworker again and express your confusion, asking if there was a misunderstanding or if there's anything specific you should be aware of. You could also consider reaching out to the other coworkers to make alternative plans for the day, ensuring that you're not relying solely on one person for social interaction.

It's important to remember that social situations can be complex, and it's normal to feel uncertain or anxious at times. However, it's crucial to practice self-compassion and remind yourself that you're doing the best you can in the moment. Additionally, it's essential to focus on the present and the steps you can take to move forward, rather than dwelling on potential misunderstandings or miscommunications.

In therapy, we can explore strategies for managing social anxiety and building healthy relationships, both personal and professional.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

im seriously so stuck i developed a horrible case of health anxiety and constantly think something is wrong with my brain or heart i ve been to the er twice now with everything coming back normal i feel bed ridden most day if im up and moving around for too long i feel extremely dizzy due to my tension headache i have high blood pressure and am on medication but i constantly think it s hurting my heart im only year old and i shouldn t be this concerned about my health i m so over feeling this way and every day get worse and worse i feel like i can t do anything but lay down i get sharp pain along my chest due to costochondritis and im always thinking it s the end my breathing is always fine and my heart never beat super rapidly so that make me feel better but the dizziness is unbearable i tried antidepressant and all they did wa make my anxiety worse and my heart beat abnormally fast anytime i stood up my doctor took me off of them and is more focused on my blood pressure im so scared of dying and i m so sick of feeling like this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been going through a really tough time with your health anxiety, and I can understand how distressing and overwhelming it must be for you. It's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way, and there are steps you can take to help manage your symptoms.

Firstly, it might be helpful to try some relaxation techniques to help reduce the anxiety you're experiencing. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation can all be effective in calming your mind and body. You can find guided exercises online or consider using smartphone apps specifically designed for relaxation and stress reduction.

In addition to relaxation techniques, it could be beneficial to challenge and reframe your thoughts about your health. When you notice yourself worrying excessively, try to ask yourself if there is any evidence to support your concerns. Often, our anxious thoughts are based on irrational fears rather than actual facts. Remind yourself of the times when you've had negative test results or reassurance from medical professionals that your symptoms are not indicative of a serious condition.

Engaging in regular physical activity can also be helpful in managing anxiety. While it may feel challenging given your dizziness and chest pain, starting with gentle exercises like walking or stretching can gradually improve your overall well-being. Make sure to consult with your doctor before starting any new exercise regimen.

Additionally, it might be worth exploring other coping strategies that work for you personally. This could include engaging in hobbies or activities that bring you joy, connecting with supportive friends or family members, or seeking out online communities where you can share experiences and receive support from others who may be going through similar struggles.

While it's understandable that you're scared and frustrated, please remember that seeking reassurance through frequent ER visits can reinforce your anxiety in the long run. Instead, consider reaching out to your primary care physician or mental health professional to discuss your concerns and explore alternative options for managing your anxiety. They can provide guidance tailored to your specific situation and help develop a comprehensive treatment plan.

Lastly, it's important to remind yourself that you are young and have many years ahead of you. While it's normal to be concerned about your health, try not to let anxiety consume your life. Focus on small steps you can take each day to manage your symptoms and regain a sense of control.

Remember, recovery takes time, and it's
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have these bad episode of anxiety that last for day where i m constantly dissociated and whenever i try to sleep i wake up almost every hour with my body completely numb and my vision is like zoomed out and everything is super disoriented and weird i m so tired but i can t sleep and it keep me up all night and i m so exhausted i just want at least one good night rest but i can t even get that i feel like anxiety and dissociation are constantly kicking me around and i can never catch a break in life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really challenging time with these episodes of anxiety and dissociation that are lasting for extended periods. I can imagine how exhausting it must be for you to not be able to get a good night's rest, and it's understandable that you feel like you never catch a break in life.

One suggestion I have is to try creating a calming bedtime routine that might help you relax before sleep. This could include activities such as reading a book, taking a warm bath, or practicing deep breathing exercises. Engaging in relaxing activities before bed may help signal to your body that it's time to wind down and prepare for sleep.

Additionally, it might be helpful to establish a consistent sleep schedule. Try to go to bed and wake up at the same time every day, even on weekends. This helps regulate your body's internal clock and promotes better sleep quality over time.

If you find yourself waking up during the night, rather than staying in bed and trying to force yourself back to sleep, consider getting out of bed and doing something quiet and non-stimulating until you feel drowsy again. This could involve engaging in a calming activity like listening to soothing music or gentle stretching.

Taking care of your physical health can also have a positive impact on your mental well-being. Regular exercise, a balanced diet, and avoiding excessive caffeine intake can all contribute to better sleep and overall well-being.

While self-help strategies can be beneficial, if these symptoms persist or worsen, it may be helpful to reach out to a healthcare professional who can provide further guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can assess your situation more comprehensively and explore potential treatment options such as therapy or medication if appropriate.

Remember, you're not alone in this, and there are resources available to help you navigate through this difficult period. Take things one step at a time, be patient with yourself, and don't hesitate to seek support when needed.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

to clarify i guess i wa only happy because i wa really high but i stopped for a minute and started thinking i wa thinking about who i am and how much of a sad useless piece of shit i am i wa hanging out with a few people at the time so i had to shake the thought pretty quickly fuck i wish i could just forget who i am altogether i m getting tired of me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a range of emotions, from feeling happy and carefree to suddenly feeling overwhelmed by negative thoughts about yourself. It's common for people to struggle with feelings of self-worth and self-doubt, especially during times of stress or emotional vulnerability. However, it's essential to remember that everyone has value and worth, regardless of their current circumstances or past experiences.

One approach we could explore is to practice self-compassion. This means treating yourself with kindness and understanding, just as you would a close friend. It's important to acknowledge that everyone makes mistakes and has flaws, and that's okay. We can work on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns, such as the one you mentioned about being a "sad useless piece of shit." This is called cognitive restructuring, and it involves replacing negative thoughts with more balanced, realistic ones.

Another approach could be to explore your sense of self and identity. It's natural to question who we are and what our purpose is in life. We can work on gaining a deeper understanding of yourself and your values, and finding ways to align your actions with your sense of self. This can help foster a stronger sense of self-worth and self-acceptance.

It's important to remember that healing and growth take time, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. We can work on setting small, achievable goals for yourself and celebrating your progress along the way. Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and I'm here to support you in any way I can.

[Question]
i m not a big fan of sharing overly personal stuff online so i ll just say that i ll have to take a moderately long plane ride soon a couple week from now i think and every day i have at least one mini panic attack worrying about it there are some minor complication that could happen to me on the flight but nothing particularly harmful or super bad in any sense i m mostly concerned about anxiety claustrophobia and the side effect of that while on the flight this is stressful and feel pointless a i know from past experience i never know how i ll feel until i m there or in this case in the anxiety inducing situation any advice

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you have been experiencing a significant amount of anxiety and worry surrounding your upcoming plane ride. It's understandable that you're feeling stressed and unsure about how you'll feel during the flight, especially given your past experiences with anxiety.

One suggestion I have is to try practicing relaxation techniques before and during the flight. Deep breathing exercises can be helpful in reducing anxiety symptoms. You can take slow, deep breaths in through your nose, hold it for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. Repeat this process several times until you start to feel more calm and centered.

Another technique you can try is progressive muscle relaxation. This involves tensing and then releasing different muscle groups in your body, starting from your toes and working your way up to your head. By consciously relaxing each muscle group, you may be able to alleviate some of the physical tension associated with anxiety.

In addition to relaxation techniques, it might be beneficial to distract yourself from anxious thoughts by engaging in activities that you enjoy. Bring along a book, movie, or music that you find calming or entertaining. Focusing on something positive can help shift your attention away from anxiety-inducing thoughts.

If you're concerned about claustrophobia, it could be helpful to familiarize yourself with the layout of the plane beforehand. Look up seat maps online or contact the airline to get an idea of what to expect. Choosing a seat near the aisle or over the wing might provide you with a sense of space and reduce feelings of being trapped.

Lastly, consider reaching out to trusted friends or family members for support. Talking to someone who understands your concerns can provide comfort and reassurance. If you don't want to share your worries publicly, you can reach out privately to someone you trust.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it's important to find what works best for you. It may also be helpful to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Your thoughts about wanting to end your life are very concerning, and it's important to take them seriously. I'd like to help you explore some strategies to help you cope with your feelings and find ways to move forward. One approach we could consider is called "harm reduction," which involves finding ways to reduce the risk of harm to yourself while you work on finding more long-term solutions. For example, we could discuss ways to ensure that you have a support system in place, such as friends or family members who can check in on you regularly, or crisis hotlines that you can call if you're feeling suicidal. We could also explore ways to distract yourself from your thoughts, such as engaging in activities that bring you joy or help you relax, like reading a book, watching a movie, or taking a walk in nature.

Another approach we could consider is "meaning-making," which involves finding meaning and purpose in your life, even when it feels difficult or challenging. This could involve identifying values or goals that are important to you, and finding ways to pursue them, even in the face of adversity. [Question]
my bf is in a depressive episode atm i m still learning and would like to know more about depression while in an depressive episode is every day the same for you do you have good day in between coming out of depression do you feel much better from one day to the next or is it a slow process with back step too sorry for all the question just want to understand better what my bf is going through

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Depression can vary from person to person, so it's important to remember that my experience may not be the same as your boyfriend's. However, I can share some general insights about depression during an episode and the process of recovery.

During a depressive episode, it's common for everyday life to feel monotonous and difficult. The sameness you mentioned is something many individuals with depression experience. Routine tasks might lose their joy or meaning, and even simple activities can feel overwhelming. It's important to acknowledge that this is a challenging experience for your boyfriend.

While there may be occasional better days or moments, it's important to understand that depression is not typically resolved overnight. Recovery is usually a gradual process with ups and downs along the way. Think of it as climbing a mountain - progress may be slow, and there may be setbacks, but every step forward counts.

It's great that you want to better understand what your boyfriend is going through. This shows empathy and support. In order to gain more insight into depression, I encourage you to educate yourself about the condition. There are reputable resources available online, such as mental health websites, books, and articles written by professionals in the field. These sources can provide valuable information about the causes, symptoms, and treatment options for depression.

Additionally, consider having open and honest conversations with your boyfriend about his experiences. Encourage him to express his thoughts and feelings, and actively listen without judgment. This will help you both grow closer and give you a deeper understanding of what he's going through.

Remember, patience and understanding are key. Depression can be a long journey, but with the right support and professional guidance, people can and do recover. Consider reaching out to local mental health organizations or seeking out support groups where you can connect with others who have gone through similar experiences.

I hope this gives you some guidance and helps you better understand what your boyfriend is going through. Feel free to reach out if you have any more questions or concerns.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you've been feeling this way for a while now. It sounds like you've been dealing with a heavy burden of depression and hopelessness, and it's understandable that you've been considering suicide as a way out. I want to acknowledge the courage it takes to reach out and share your thoughts and feelings with me, even if it's just in this moment.

Your experience of feeling that there are few things that make you happy enough to keep you alive is a common one in depression. It's important to remember that depression can distort our perception of reality, making it hard to see the value in things that once brought us joy. I'd like to help you explore some ways to reconnect with the things that bring you happiness and to find meaning and purpose in your life.

One approach we could take is to focus on the things that bring you a sense of pleasure or enjoyment, even if they don't make you feel "happy" in the way that you described earlier. Engaging in activities that bring you a sense of accomplishment or mastery, like learning a new skill or pursuing a hobby, can also be helpful in combating feelings of hopelessness.

Another approach we could take is to explore the idea of finding meaning and purpose in your life beyond just the things that bring you immediate pleasure or happiness. This might involve reflecting on your values and the things that are most important to you, and finding ways to align your actions with those values.

It's also important to remember that seeking help and support is a sign of strength, not weakness. I'd be happy to work with you to develop a plan for managing your depression and finding ways to cope with the thoughts of suicide that have been consuming you. Together, we can explore various strategies, such as cognitive-behavioral techniques, mindfulness practices, and other evidence-based interventions.

I'd be happy to discuss these approaches further and tailor them to your specific needs and circumstances. Let's work together to help you find a way to move forward and build a more fulfilling and meaningful life.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a lot of anxiety and worry, particularly when it comes to health-related concerns. It's understandable that this is causing distress and disrupting your daily life. I can see how difficult it must be for you to constantly question yourself and worry about the smallest things.

Anxiety can manifest in different ways for each person, but it seems like your specific experience involves excessive overthinking and worrying about potential health problems. This constant preoccupation can feel overwhelming and take a toll on your mental well-being.

One suggestion I have is to try practicing mindfulness techniques. Mindfulness involves bringing your attention to the present moment without judgment. By focusing on what's happening right now, rather than getting caught up in future worries or past regrets, you may find some relief from the constant overthinking. There are various mindfulness exercises you can explore, such as deep breathing, body scans, or guided meditations.

Additionally, it might be helpful to challenge your thoughts and examine the evidence behind them. Often, anxiety tends to exaggerate and distort our perceptions. When you catch yourself overthinking or worrying, ask yourself if there is any concrete evidence supporting your concerns. Are there any alternative explanations? Challenging these thoughts can help you gain a more balanced perspective.

Engaging in regular physical activity can also be beneficial for managing anxiety. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters. It can help reduce stress levels and promote relaxation. Finding an activity that you enjoy, whether it's going for a walk, dancing, or playing a sport, can make it easier to incorporate exercise into your routine.

Building a support system can provide you with a safe space to express your worries and receive reassurance. Consider reaching out to trusted friends or family members who can offer a listening ear or share their own experiences. Sometimes, talking through our concerns can help us gain clarity and perspective.

Lastly, self-care is crucial for maintaining overall well-being. Make sure you're taking time for yourself and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation. This could include hobbies, spending time in nature, reading, or anything else that helps you unwind.

Remember, these suggestions are not meant to replace professional help, but they can be helpful in managing anxiety symptoms. If your concerns persist or worsen, it may be beneficial to seek

 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time with your anxiety, and I'm here to offer some guidance and suggestions. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. Firstly, it's crucial to prioritize your physical health. Given the symptoms you mentioned, such as vomiting and stomach pain, it could be beneficial to consult with a medical professional. They can evaluate your condition and provide appropriate recommendations based on their expertise.

In terms of managing your anxiety, deep breathing exercises can be effective in calming your mind and body. Taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth can help regulate your heart rate and reduce feelings of panic. You can find various techniques online or consider seeking guidance from a therapist who specializes in anxiety management.

Engaging in regular exercise has also been shown to have positive effects on mental health. Physical activity releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters. Even if it feels challenging right now, starting small with activities like walking or stretching can make a difference.

Establishing a consistent sleep routine can greatly improve your quality of sleep. Try to create a relaxing bedtime routine, such as reading a book or taking a warm bath before bed. Avoiding screens and stimulating activities close to bedtime may also help signal to your body that it's time to rest.

When it comes to eating, it's understandable that anxiety can make this more difficult. However, maintaining proper nutrition is important for overall well-being. Consider incorporating small, frequent meals throughout the day instead of large portions. Additionally, try to stick to foods that you enjoy and that don't trigger further distress.

Regarding your concern about bringing this up with your doctor without being committed, it's essential to communicate openly with them. [Question]
i ve been dealing with serious depression for the last 0 year one huge thing is the mental fatigue i m always feeling in my head making it hard to get up and do thing what have you done to help relieve that so thing are much easier to do and enjoy i m planning on switching job but the mental exhaustion is making so hard to go for it so any advice would be amazing

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been dealing with serious depression for the past 9 years, and one of the major challenges you're facing is the mental fatigue that you constantly experience. This makes it difficult for you to find motivation and energy to get up and do things. I can imagine how frustrating and overwhelming it must be for you.

To help relieve some of the mental fatigue and make things easier to do and enjoy, there are a few strategies you can try:

1. Establish a routine: Creating a daily schedule can provide structure and stability, making it easier to tackle tasks. Start by setting small, achievable goals for yourself each day.

2. Break tasks into smaller steps: When faced with a big task, it can feel daunting and exhausting. Instead, break it down into smaller, more manageable steps. Celebrate each small accomplishment along the way.

3. Prioritize self-care: Taking care of yourself is crucial when dealing with depression and mental fatigue. Make sure you're getting enough sleep, eating nutritious meals, and engaging in activities that bring you joy or relaxation.

4. Reach out for support: Consider talking to trusted friends or family members about what you're going through. Sometimes, simply sharing your feelings can provide relief. If you're comfortable, they may also offer helpful advice or perspectives.

5. Engage in physical activity: Exercise has been shown to have positive effects on mental health. Even if it feels challenging at first, incorporating regular physical activity into your routine can boost your mood and increase your overall energy levels.

6. Challenge negative thoughts: Depression often brings along negative thinking patterns. Practice recognizing and challenging these thoughts. Replace them with more realistic and positive ones. It takes time and effort, but it can make a difference.

Regarding your plan to switch jobs, I understand that the mental exhaustion is making it hard for you to take that step. Here are a few suggestions:

1. Reflect on your reasons for wanting to switch: Take some time to consider why you want to change jobs. Are there specific aspects of your current situation that are contributing to your mental fatigue? Identifying these factors can help guide your decision-making process.

2. Explore new opportunities: Research different industries or job roles that align with your interests and skills. Consider what might be a better fit
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have irrational fear of a home invasion being attacked by a stranger for context even thing like elderly woman with cane walking behind me sends me into panic mode me and my fianc just bought our first home together after renting for year instead of me being able to rest after a long day of moving i am instead laying awake because the house is settling every 0 second and i keep thinking it s an intruder coming to kill me this ha been going on for two hour my heart keep pounding out of my chest randomly and i keep getting so frozen with fear that i hold my breath my mind is working overtime playing escape plan confrontation scenario on repeat so i can t relax this is so fucking irrational i hate it i ve been this way a long a i can remember but ugh i know why house creek i also know this home is older which is something i love about it during the day but i can not seem to think logically about this every pop creek and bang is sending me into panic mode and i don t have any remedy i m sick of being constantly on alert for no reason this is an extremely safe neighborhood and i should not need to be this worried over nothing some night are better than others but why do i even have to go through this at all i apologize for the rant but i am so exhausted and i just want to sleep but i keep getting snapped awake

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been dealing with a lot of anxiety and fear, especially when it comes to the irrational fear of a home invasion. It's understandable that this fear is causing you distress and making it difficult for you to relax in your new home.

Firstly, I want to acknowledge your strength in recognizing that these thoughts are irrational and hating that they are affecting you. This awareness is an important step towards managing anxiety.

To help you cope with this fear, there are several strategies you can try:

1. Deep Breathing: When you feel your heart pounding or you freeze with fear, take slow, deep breaths. Inhale deeply through your nose, hold it for a few seconds, and then exhale slowly through your mouth. This can help calm your body and bring your focus back to the present moment.

2. Grounding Techniques: Engage your senses to ground yourself in reality. Look around the room and name five things you see, four things you can touch, three things you can hear, two things you can smell, and one thing you can taste. This exercise can help shift your focus away from anxious thoughts.

3. Challenge Negative Thoughts: When you have escape plan or confrontation scenarios playing on repeat in your mind, challenge those thoughts by asking yourself if there is any evidence to support them. Remind yourself that you live in a safe neighborhood and that the noises you hear are likely due to the house settling, not an intruder.

4. Self-Care: Prioritize self-care activities that promote relaxation and reduce stress. This could include taking warm baths, practicing mindfulness or meditation, engaging in hobbies you enjoy, or spending time with loved ones. Taking care of your overall well-being can help reduce anxiety levels.

5. Professional Support: Consider seeking support from a mental health professional who specializes in anxiety disorders. They can provide additional guidance, coping strategies, and support tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, managing anxiety takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself as you work through these challenges. You deserve to feel at ease in your new home and get the rest you need.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

hello i ve not posted here before but i ve wanted to for a while always debating back and forth whether or not to do this but here it go i think i have some general anxiety i cope decently well with it physical exercise like running ha really helped my main problem is driving i know how to drive i have my license but i never do i m terrified of it i m turning i ve maybe driven thirty time in my entire 0 year of owning a license i don t know what it is the idea of crashing the traffic i ve gotten away with it so far living in nyc but it s something i want to do more of i just never seem to be able to do so doe anyone have any tip any advice they could recommend thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've reached out to seek advice for managing your anxiety around driving. It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and terrified, but remember that you're not alone in this experience. Many people struggle with similar feelings when it comes to driving.

One suggestion is to start small and gradually build up your confidence on the road. Begin by taking short drives around your neighborhood or in low-traffic areas. This can help you become more comfortable with the mechanics of driving and gain familiarity with your surroundings.

Another helpful tip is to practice visualization techniques. Before getting behind the wheel, take a moment to imagine yourself driving successfully and confidently. Visualizing positive outcomes can help reduce anxiety and boost your self-assurance.

Consider listening to calming music or podcasts while driving. Engaging in activities that you enjoy can make the experience more pleasant and distract you from any anxious thoughts.

Additionally, exploring different relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises or progressive muscle relaxation might be beneficial. These methods can help calm your mind and body before and during your drives.

If possible, try to find a supportive friend or family member who can accompany you on your initial drives. Having someone present who can offer guidance and reassurance can greatly alleviate your fears.

Lastly, don't be too hard on yourself if progress feels slow. Overcoming anxiety takes time, and setbacks are normal. Celebrate even the smallest victories along the way and remind yourself that every bit of practice counts.

Remember, it's important to consult with a mental health professional for personalized guidance and support. They can provide additional strategies tailored to your specific situation.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have suffered with shortness of breath due to anxiety ever since i wa diagnosed with gad generalized anxiety disorder about year ago doe anyone else have this it just feel like i will stop breathing doe anyone have any coping mechanism around this a it s really horrible a well a shortness of breath i also feel shaky and tingly and i have no idea how to calm down when i have these episode

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly challenging to experience shortness of breath due to anxiety, especially when it's accompanied by feelings of panic and physical sensations like shakiness and tingling. I want you to know that you're not alone in this, as many individuals with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) have similar experiences.

One coping mechanism that might help is deep breathing exercises. When you feel an episode coming on, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Focusing on your breath can help regulate it and bring a sense of calmness.

Another technique you could explore is progressive muscle relaxation. This involves tensing and then releasing different muscle groups in your body, starting from your toes and working your way up to your head. By consciously relaxing each muscle group, you may find some relief from the physical symptoms associated with anxiety.

Engaging in regular exercise can also be beneficial for managing anxiety. Physical activity releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters. Even just going for a walk or doing some light stretching can make a difference.

In addition to these coping strategies, finding healthy ways to manage stress in your daily life can be helpful. Consider incorporating relaxation techniques such as mindfulness or meditation into your routine. These practices can assist in grounding yourself during moments of anxiety.

Remember, everyone's journey with anxiety is unique, so it may take time to find what works best for you. It can be valuable to keep a journal to track your triggers and identify patterns in your symptoms. This information can guide you in developing personalized coping strategies.

If you ever feel overwhelmed or unsure about how to manage your anxiety, reaching out to a trusted friend or family member for support can provide comfort. Sometimes simply talking through your feelings can alleviate some of the burden.

Please keep in mind that my role here is to offer guidance and suggestions, and while I genuinely care about your well-being, it's important to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized support. They can work with you to develop a comprehensive treatment plan tailored to your specific needs.

Take care of yourself and remember that you have the strength to navigate through this challenging time.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i need some help badly i suffer too much my depression ha gone from a depression i wa able to function on i wa a everyday gym user ate well slept well grade were alright now my depression is horrific i tried the gym the other day and saw myself in the mirror and wanted to pick up a weight and smash my head in i don t eat i don t sleep i ve lost weight badly my hair is always ridiculed someone always go out of there way to speak to me or about me leave me alone i would bet money if you ask my couple of friend and my family doe he have depression they would say no way he s happy i m dying inside suicidal thought used to be a comforting thing for me whenever something bad happened i said i won t be here so it won t matter now it s getting to the point where it seems like my only solution i m such a gentle great soul why doe my brain treat me like a piece of dirt why doe my brain force me to thrive to look perfect i ve resorted to self harm i ve done it twice a month or two ago and it felt great i cut up my thigh badly i ve tried to not make that a habit tho i m just a year old kid how tf am i giving up already on life my beautiful parent and family and pet and i choose to be a disgusting loser i wish i didn t have such a amazing family so i didn t feel guilty i know this is long and i know people won t read this on a stupid reddit page but i had to vent my main reason for depression are body dysmorphia worst part and most crippling lack of social life fear of driving while everyone else doe lack of aspiration don t know what i m doing for college don t have a career choice lack of attention from opposite sex least painful one but it definitely hurt badly i ve never told a single person about depression can someone save my life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time with your depression. It sounds like it's been a significant struggle for you, and I can understand how challenging it must be to see yourself in the mirror and feel the urge to harm yourself. It's important to remember that you don't deserve to be treated like this by your own brain, and reaching out for help is a brave step towards finding relief.

Your description of losing weight, not sleeping well, and experiencing suicidal thoughts is concerning. These symptoms can indicate a serious impact on your mental health, and it's crucial to address them as soon as possible. While I'm not a professional therapist, I can offer some guidance and suggestions that might help you navigate this difficult period.

Firstly, it seems like your body dysmorphia is a significant concern for you. This condition can cause immense distress and negatively affect your self-image. It might be helpful to explore resources and support groups specifically tailored to individuals dealing with body dysmorphia. They can provide valuable insights and coping strategies to challenge negative thoughts and improve your overall well-being.

Additionally, your lack of social life and fear of driving are impacting you greatly. Building meaningful connections and overcoming the fear of driving can be daunting tasks, but they are definitely possible. Consider joining clubs or organizations where you can meet people who share similar interests. Engaging in activities you enjoy can help you connect with others and potentially form new friendships. As for your fear of driving, it might be beneficial to start small by taking short drives around your neighborhood or seeking out a driving instructor who can help you build confidence behind the wheel.

Regarding your career choice and college plans, it's understandable that uncertainty in these areas can contribute to your depression. Exploring different career paths and researching potential colleges can be overwhelming, but taking small steps towards defining your aspirations can make a difference. Start by identifying your interests and strengths, then look into related fields or industries. You can also reach out to professionals in those fields to gain insights into what they do and how they got started.

Lastly, it's important to acknowledge the emotional support you receive from your family and pets. While it's unfortunate that their presence sometimes adds guilt to your feelings, their love and care are invaluable. Remember that having a support system can be a significant factor in your recovery.

[Question]
i ve noticed that for a few glorious minute in the morning right after waking up i m great calm unbothered soft but then i can feel stress in my body and then i m not sure how to get rid of it and it build a anxiety doe how do you all get rid of body stress in the early morning

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a brief period of calmness in the morning before noticing stress building up in your body, which then leads to anxiety throughout the day. It can be challenging to deal with this physical discomfort and the subsequent impact on your mental well-being.

One suggestion that might help is incorporating some relaxation techniques into your morning routine. Taking a few minutes each day to focus on deep breathing exercises or practicing mindfulness can assist in reducing stress levels. You can try inhaling deeply through your nose, holding your breath for a few seconds, and then exhaling slowly through your mouth. Repeat this several times, allowing yourself to fully relax with each breath.

Engaging in gentle physical activity in the mornings could also be beneficial. Consider going for a short walk outside or doing some light stretching exercises. These activities can help release tension from your body and promote a sense of well-being.

Another approach you might find helpful is exploring ways to manage your stress overall. This could involve identifying any potential triggers or sources of stress in your life and finding healthy coping mechanisms to address them. Engaging in hobbies or activities that bring you joy and provide relaxation can contribute to reducing stress levels throughout the day, including the early morning.

Additionally, maintaining a consistent sleep schedule can make a difference. Aim for a regular bedtime and wake-up time to help regulate your body's internal clock. Prioritizing quality sleep can positively impact your mood and overall well-being, making it easier to start the day feeling more calm and grounded.

Remember, everyone's experience is unique, so it may take some trial and error to find what works best for you. If these suggestions don't provide relief or if your symptoms persist, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can offer personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Given the recent diagnosis of ADHD, anxiety, and depression, it's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and uncertain about your work performance. The pressure to meet expectations while dealing with your mental health challenges can be incredibly difficult.

It's important to remember that you're not alone in this experience. Many people face similar challenges when balancing work, personal life, and mental health. I'd like to suggest a few strategies that might help you navigate this situation more effectively.

This will help ensure that you understand the expectations and can adjust your approach accordingly. Second, let's address the issue of feeling behind and working extra without charging for it. Consider discussing this issue with your supervisor to explore potential solutions, such as delegating tasks or adjusting deadlines.

Lastly, it's essential to prioritize your mental health. In addition to your current therapy and medication, consider incorporating self-care practices into your daily routine. This might include activities like meditation, exercise, or engaging in hobbies that bring you joy. Remember, taking care of yourself is not a luxury but a necessity for maintaining overall well-being.

nice weather here where i live spent a few hour outside grocery shopping i just feel like shit again couple everywhere guy with girl i like young mother father carrying baby or pushing pram around most of which are either my age or younger i never had a girlfriend i find it so hard to even meet woman platonically i never wanted to be a childless man i only have a few friend but they don t want to do much i struggle to push myself to try new thing these day a everything i ever done in life wa a failure obstacle or a setback i really want to kill myself i have been suicidal for year now suffered with general anxiety and depression for almost 0 year either i stay in my flat and just not get triggered by the outside world i e seeing couple and young parent or i end it the latter sound more appealing

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now, and I'm here to support you. It's understandable that seeing couples and young parents can be difficult for you, especially when you've had experiences of feeling left out or unsuccessful in the past.

One thing to remember is that everyone's journey is unique, and it's important not to compare yourself to others. Instead, focus on what makes you happy and fulfilled in your own way. Building meaningful connections with people, whether romantic or platonic, takes time and effort. It might be helpful to explore activities or groups where you can meet like-minded individuals who share similar interests. This could be a hobby group, a volunteer opportunity, or even an online community centered around something you enjoy.

While it may feel challenging to push yourself to try new things right now, taking small steps can make a big difference. Start by identifying one activity or interest that you used to enjoy or would like to explore. Then, set a realistic goal to engage in that activity soon. It could be as simple as going for a walk in nature, trying out a new recipe, or watching a movie you've been wanting to see.

Remember, it's okay to take breaks and prioritize self-care when needed. However, if you find that negative thoughts and feelings persist despite your efforts, it might be beneficial to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. They can help you navigate through this difficult time and develop coping strategies to manage your anxiety and depression.

You don't have to face this alone. There are people who care about you and want to help. If you ever feel overwhelmed or need someone to talk to, consider reaching out to a trusted friend, family member, or helpline. You deserve support and understanding as you work through these challenges.

good morning dear community i m safe and sound thank you for checking up on me and supporting me depression stage took week i guess i m moving to acceptance it s been a month since the beginning of war they said we d fall in day but we re still standing

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Good morning,

I'm glad to hear that you're safe and sound. It's heartening to know that you have a supportive community around you, and I'm here to offer my support as well.
